TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi sealed beforefieldinit SignerInfo extends System.Object

Docs.summary: The class represents a signer associated with a object that represents a CMS/PKCS #7 message.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The signatures represented by the <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.Pkcs.SignerInfo> class can be either over message content or a signature. The latter kind of signature is referred to as a *countersignature*.
This implementation of CMS/PKCS #7 supports only one level of countersignature. That is, a signature can be signed, which forms a countersignature, but that countersignature cannot be signed again.
This class does not have a public constructor; therefore, it cannot be publicly instantiated. It is a read-only class accessible from the <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.Pkcs.SignedCms.SignerInfos%2A?displayProperty=fullName> property.

Docs.summary: The property retrieves the signing certificate associated with the signer information.
Docs.value: An object that represents the signing certificate.

remarks.format: ## Remarks If the signing certificate is not included at signing time by using the <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.Pkcs.CmsSigner.IncludeOption%2A?displayProperty=fullName> property, then the certificate will not be returned.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig instance void CheckHash() cil managed

Docs.summary: The method verifies the data integrity of the CMS/PKCS #7 message signer information. is a specialized method used in specific security infrastructure applications in which the subject uses the **HashOnly** member of the enumeration when setting up a object. does not authenticate the signer information because this method does not involve verifying a digital signature. For general-purpose checking of the integrity and authenticity of CMS/PKCS #7 message signer information and countersignatures, use the or methods.

remarks.format: ## Remarks This method does not provide authentication of the CMS/PKCS #7 message signer information.

Docs.exception: A cryptographic operation could not be completed.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig instance void CheckSignature(bool verifySignatureOnly) cil managed

Docs.param: A bool value that specifies whether only the digital signature is verified. If verifySignatureOnly is , only the signature is verified. If verifySignatureOnly is , the digital signature is verified, the certificate chain is validated, and the purposes of the certificates are validated. The purposes of the certificate are considered valid if the certificate has no key usage or if the key usage supports digital signature or nonrepudiation.
Docs.summary: The method verifies the digital signature of the message and, optionally, validates the certificate.

remarks.format:
## Remarks This method throws an exception if the verification of the digital signature fails or any validation requirements are not met.
If more complex validation is required, the caller can specify that only the signature is verified and then use an <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509Chain> object to perform custom validation.

Docs.exception: A null reference was passed to a method that does not accept it as a valid argument.
A cryptographic operation could not be completed.
A method call was invalid for the object's current state.

MemberSignature.Value: public void CheckSignature (System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509Certificate2Collection extraStore, bool verifySignatureOnly);
.method public hidebysig instance void CheckSignature(class System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509Certificate2Collection extraStore, bool verifySignatureOnly) cil managed

Docs.param: An object that can be used to validate the chain. If no additional certificates are to be used to validate the chain, use instead of .

A bool value that specifies whether only the digital signature is verified. If verifySignatureOnly is , only the signature is verified. If verifySignatureOnly is , the digital signature is verified, the certificate chain is validated, and the purposes of the certificates are validated. The purposes of the certificate are considered valid if the certificate has no key usage or if the key usage supports digital signature or nonrepudiation.
Docs.summary: The method verifies the digital signature of the message by using the specified collection of certificates and, optionally, validates the certificate.

remarks.format:
## Remarks This method throws an exception if the verification of the digital signature fails or any validation requirements are not met.
If more complex validation is required, the caller can specify that only the signature is verified and then use an <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509Chain> object to perform custom validation.

Docs.exception: A null reference was passed to a method that does not accept it as a valid argument.
A cryptographic operation could not be completed.
A method call was invalid for the object's current state.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig instance void ComputeCounterSignature() cil managed

Docs.summary: The method prompts the user to select a signing certificate, creates a countersignature, and adds the signature to the CMS/PKCS #7 message. Countersignatures are restricted to one level.

remarks.format:
## Remarks This implementation of CMS/PKCS #7 supports only one level of countersignature. That is, a signature can be signed, which forms a countersignature, but that countersignature cannot be signed again.
This method displays a user interface in which you choose signers for this message. This requires that the current process is running in *user interactive mode*, meaning that the <xref:System.Environment.UserInteractive%2A?displayProperty=fullName> property is set to `true`. A process is normally in user interactive mode unless it is a service process or running inside a Web application.
Signers whose certificates meet the following conditions will be displayed in the list:
- The certificate has an associated private key.
- The certificate is within its validity period.
- The certificate has no key usage or a key usage that supports digital signatures or nonrepudiation.
Signer certificates are chosen from the My store.
## .NET Framework Security The following permissions are required to display the user interface:
- <xref:System.Security.Permissions.UIPermissionWindow?displayProperty=fullName>
The following permissions are required to access the signature key:
- <xref:System.Security.Permissions.KeyContainerPermissionFlags?displayProperty=fullName>
- <xref:System.Security.Permissions.KeyContainerPermissionFlags?displayProperty=fullName>

Docs.exception: A null reference was passed to a method that does not accept it as a valid argument.
A cryptographic operation could not be completed.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig instance void ComputeCounterSignature(class System.Security.Cryptography.Pkcs.CmsSigner signer) cil managed

Docs.param: A object that represents the counter signer.
Docs.summary: The method creates a countersignature by using the specified signer and adds the signature to the CMS/PKCS #7 message. Countersignatures are restricted to one level.

remarks.format:
## Remarks This implementation of CMS/PKCS #7 supports only one level of countersignature. That is, a signature can be signed, which forms a countersignature, but that countersignature cannot be signed again.
## .NET Framework Security The following permissions are required to access the signature key:
- <xref:System.Security.Permissions.KeyContainerPermissionFlags?displayProperty=fullName>
- <xref:System.Security.Permissions.KeyContainerPermissionFlags?displayProperty=fullName>

A cryptographic operation could not be completed.

Docs.summary: The property retrieves the set of counter signers associated with the signer information.
Docs.value: A collection that represents the counter signers for the signer information. If there are no counter signers, the property is an empty collection.

remarks.format: ## Remarks This implementation of CMS/PKCS #7 supports only one level of countersignature. That is, a signature can be signed, which forms a countersignature, but that countersignature cannot be signed again.

Docs.summary: The property retrieves the object that represents the hash algorithm used in the computation of the signatures.
Docs.value: An object that represents the hash algorithm used with the signature.

Docs.param: The zero-based index of the countersignature to remove.
Docs.summary: The method removes the countersignature at the specified index of the collection.
Docs.exception: A cryptographic operation could not be completed.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig instance void RemoveCounterSignature(class System.Security.Cryptography.Pkcs.SignerInfo counterSignerInfo) cil managed

Docs.param: A object that represents the countersignature being removed.
Docs.summary: The method removes the countersignature for the specified object.
Docs.exception: A null reference was passed to a method that does not accept it as a valid argument.
The value of an argument was outside the allowable range of values as defined by the called method.
A cryptographic operation could not be completed.

Docs.summary: The property retrieves the collection of signed attributes that is associated with the signer information. Signed attributes are signed along with the rest of the message content.
Docs.value: A collection that represents the signed attributes. If there are no signed attributes, the property is an empty collection.

remarks.format:
## Remarks An example of a signed attribute that might be included in the <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.CryptographicAttributeObjectCollection> collection retrieved by the <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.Pkcs.SignerInfo.SignedAttributes%2A> property is the <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.Pkcs.Pkcs9SigningTime> signing time attribute.
Signed attributes are signed along with the rest of the <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.Pkcs.SignedCms> message content. This means that a party that successfully verifies the signature can have confidence that the contents of these attributes are authentic and have not been altered.
A <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.Pkcs.Pkcs9ContentType> object and a <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.Pkcs.Pkcs9MessageDigest> object will be automatically generated and placed in the <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.Pkcs.SignerInfo.SignedAttributes%2A> property whenever the <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.Pkcs.CmsSigner.SignedAttributes%2A?displayProperty=fullName> property for the corresponding signer is not empty.

Docs.summary: The property retrieves the certificate identifier of the signer associated with the signer information.
Docs.value: A object that uniquely identifies the certificate associated with the signer information.

Docs.summary: The property retrieves the collection of unsigned attributes that is associated with the content. Unsigned attributes can be modified without invalidating the signature.
Docs.value: A collection that represents the unsigned attributes. If there are no unsigned attributes, the property is an empty collection.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Unsigned attributes are not signed along with the rest of the <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.Pkcs.SignedCms> message content. Even though a party successfully verifies the signature, the unsigned attributes may have been altered and should not be considered to have authenticity or integrity.
An example of an unsigned attribute that might be included in the <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.CryptographicAttributeObjectCollection> collection retrieved by the <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.Pkcs.SignerInfo.UnsignedAttributes%2A> property is a countersignature.

Docs.summary: The property retrieves the signer information version.
Docs.value: An int value that specifies the signer information version.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The version determines whether the message is a PKCS #7 message or a Cryptographic Message Syntax (CMS) message. CMS is a newer superset of PKCS #7.
